block.p: Spicy lasagne, calamari salad and the house's signature ''humongous'' veal chops arrive at the regulars' red leather booths. Sinatra is on perpetual repeat on the speakers. The walls are crowded with pictures of the Lackawanna train station and the Clam Broth House, along with a street sign that says, misspellings and all, ''Welcome to Hoboken: Brithplace of Frank Sinatra and Baseball.''

Matteo's: A Little Taste of Hoboken, in quiet Westwood, was founded 13 years ago by the late Matthew Jordan, a former trucker from the old neighborhood who wandered far but never lost the taste for Italian comfort food. The informal trattoria and take-out that sits next door to a more upscale dining room of the same name that was opened by Mr. Jordan 24 years earlier.

Transplanted Jerseyites are frequent patrons, but Matteo's has developed a strong local customer base over the years, with entree prices that range from $7.95 to $14.95 in the cafe, and up to $24.95 next door.
